title: India says new IT fact-checking unit will not censor journalism
summary: India's government clarified that its proposed fact-checking unit for social media news will not censor journalism or affect media reporting, according to a federal minister's statement.
content:
NEW DELHI, April 14 (Reuters) - A proposed Indian government unit to fact-check news on social media is not about censoring journalism nor will it have any impact on media reportage, a federal minister said on Friday.

Recently amended IT regulations require social media companies to take down content that a government-appointed fact-checking unit identifies as "fake or false." The move has sparked concerns about state censorship among journalists and media organizations.

The government maintains that the fact-checking unit is necessary to combat the spread of misinformation on social media platforms while preserving press freedom.

## Government Response to Fact-Checking Concerns

NEW DELHI, April 14 (Reuters) - A proposed Indian government unit to fact-check news on social media "is not about censoring journalism nor will it have any impact on media reportage," a federal minister said on Friday.

Recently amended IT regulations require social media companies to take down content that a government-appointed fact-checking unit identifies as "fake or false." The move has sparked concerns about state censorship among journalists and media organizations.

The government maintains that the fact-checking unit is necessary to combat the spread of misinformation on social media platforms while preserving press freedom.
